summary: A letter from defense attorneys Anthony Cecutti and Jennifer Louis-Jeune to Judge Paul A. Engelmayer regarding their client, inmate Justin Rivera. The letter details Rivera's difficulties accessing his laptop for discovery review and securing adequate video calls with counsel while detained at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). It raises concerns about staff hostility, COVID-19 safety, and contrasts his conditions unfavorably with those afforded to Ghislaine Maxwell at the MDC.

persons.context: Inmate at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) who is struggling to access his laptop for discovery review and adequate video calls with his defense counsel ahead of his scheduled trial.

persons.name: Anthony Cecutti
persons.context: Attorney representing Justin Rivera, co-author of this letter to the court detailing issues with client access to discovery and counsel.

persons.name: Jennifer Louis-Jeune

persons.name: Paul A. Engelmayer
persons.context: Judge presiding over the case United States v. Justin Rivera. The letter is addressed to him, requesting his intervention regarding MCC's handling of Rivera's access.

connections.description: Cecutti is one of Rivera's defense attorneys, advocating for his client's access to discovery and counsel.
Louis-Jeune is one of Rivera's defense attorneys, co-authoring the letter and conducting video calls with him.

events.title: Rivera Receives Laptop in SHU
events.description: Justin Rivera received his laptop for discovery review while in the Special Housing Unit (SHU), with access for at least 3 hours daily in his cell.

events.title: Rivera Denied Laptop Access
events.description: After being transferred to a general unit, Rivera was denied access to his laptop for several days because MCC staff claimed to be unaware of the court order.

events.title: Court Conference on Access Issues
events.description: A conference was held before Judge Engelmayer regarding Rivera's access to his laptop and counsel. The court directed the parties to submit a joint proposed order for video calls.

events.title: 4-Hour Video Call with Counsel
events.description: Rivera had a video call with his attorneys, Cecutti and Louis-Jeune, from 5:45 PM to 9:45 PM, as scheduled by the MCC against their preferences.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Start
events.description: Justin Rivera's trial is scheduled to begin on this date, adding urgency to the discovery review and attorney-client preparation issues.

keyFacts: Justin Rivera was called 'enemy #1' by an MCC staff member, who said staff were 'on' him because he was provided a laptop and increased video calls, raising safety concerns.
Rivera's access to his laptop for discovery was inconsistent: allowed in his SHU cell but denied in his general unit cell on weekdays, only permitted on weekends and holidays.
The MCC refused to provide Rivera with two 2-hour video calls per week with counsel as requested, instead offering one 4-hour block on Friday evenings, which was difficult for his attorneys.
The letter highlights a stark contrast in detention conditions between Justin Rivera and Ghislaine Maxwell, noting Maxwell had superior, private access to discovery and counsel in her cell.
Defense counsel argues the differential treatment appears to be based on race, gender, and class, as Rivera is not afforded the same privileges as the 'white affluent woman' Maxwell.
